page.title: 02Language in Aboyne
page.content: The Aboyne{dialect}departs only slightly from the general Aberdeenshire dialect which owes much to the ancient{language}of Gaelic, itself very similar to modern German, both in{accent}and individual{words.} It consists of a strange mixture of English and old Scots, although phrases like "whit like" (pronounced "Fit like") meaning "How are you?" are still commonly heard. Nowadays the dialect is much diluted due to the influx of English and Americans into the area, and now the broadest strain is only heard when older locals meet. Continuity in the language has been largely lost due to school_taught English although many teachers have now begun to introduce the Scottish language into the English course.
